content.question: Which of the following is played?

choices.label: Score A has one staff in the bass clef. There are no key signatures or time signatures. It has only one measure consisting of a single homophonic chord of three whole notes. The pitches in score A are: a chord of E3, G3, and C4.

Score B has one staff in the bass clef. There are no key signatures or time signatures. It has only one measure consisting of a single homophonic chord of three whole notes. The pitches in score B are: a chord of E3, G sharp 3, and C sharp 4.

Score C has one staff in the bass clef. There are no key signatures or time signatures. It has only one measure consisting of a single homophonic chord of three whole notes. The pitches in score C are: a chord of E3, A3, and C sharp 4.

Score D has one staff in the bass clef. There are no key signatures or time signatures. It has only one measure consisting of a single homophonic chord of three whole notes. The pitches in score D are: a chord of E3, A3, and C4.

content.answer: Score A has one staff in the bass clef. There are no key signatures or time signatures. It has only one measure consisting of a single homophonic chord of three whole notes. The pitches in score A are: a chord of E3, G3, and C4.

unit.text: 1: Music Fundamentals I - Pitch, Major Scales and Key Signatures, Rhythm, Meter, and Expressive Elements

topic.text: 3.1: Triad and Chord Qualities (M, m, d, A)

skill.text: Skill 1.A: Use symbols and terms to describe features of pitch in performed music, including pitch patterns and relationships, melodic features, chords, harmonic progressions, and cadences.
